image.altText: Joe Biden

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden says he is "saddened and outraged" by an explosion at a hospital in the Gaza Strip, as families are reunited at Sydney airport.

title.children: US president meets with war cabinet in Israel as second repatriation flight touches down in Sydney

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden has been asked at a media conference how he knows Israel was not behind the deadly explosion at the Gaza hospital earlier today. Biden said he based his conclusion on "the data I was shown by my Defence Department". In a separate statement, the US president said he asked Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu "tough questions" during their meeting in Tel Aviv. "I asked tough questions as a friend of Israel. We will continue to deter any actor wanting to widen this conflict," he said in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter. AP/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden says his position on the Gaza hospital blast is based on US Defence 'data'

props.alt: Portrait photo of US President Joe Biden sitting in front of an Israeli flag.

children.content: (Reuters: Evelyn Hockstein)
US President Joe Biden has been asked at a media conference how he knows Israel was not behind the deadly explosion at the Gaza hospital earlier today.
Biden said he based his conclusion on "the data I was shown by my Defence Department".
In a separate statement, the US president said he asked Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu "tough questions" during their meeting in Tel Aviv.
"I asked tough questions as a friend of Israel. We will continue to deter any actor wanting to widen this conflict," he said in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter.
AP/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: At least 3,478 people have been killed in Gaza since October 7, the Gaza health ministry has said in a statement. More than 12,000 others have been injured, the statement said. Ashraf Al-Qidra, a Gaza health ministry spokesperson, said 471 people had been killed in the Al-Ahli hospital explosion alone. The spokesperson said this "massacre" had also injured 314 people. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza death toll rises to nearly 3,500, local health ministry says

props.alt: A man sits outside his building which was destroyed during Israeli bombardment

children.content: (AP: Fatima Shbair)
At least 3,478 people have been killed in Gaza since October 7, the Gaza health ministry has said in a statement.
More than 12,000 others have been injured, the statement said.
Ashraf Al-Qidra, a Gaza health ministry spokesperson, said 471 people had been killed in the Al-Ahli hospital explosion alone.
The spokesperson said this "massacre" had also injured 314 people.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US Treasury says it has issued new sanctions aimed at disrupting the Hamas militant group's funding, citing "a secret investment portfolio". The sanctions target 10 Hamas members, operatives and financial facilitators in Gaza and elsewhere, including Sudan, Türkiye, Algeria and Qatar, the department said. "The United States is taking swift and decisive action to target Hamas’s financiers and facilitators following its brutal and unconscionable massacre of Israeli civilians, including children," Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said. "We will continue to take all steps necessary to deny Hamas terrorists the ability to raise and use funds to carry out atrocities and terrorize the people of Israel." The sanctions have been imposed under a terrorism-related executive order. "In addition to the funds Hamas receives from Iran, its global portfolio of investments generates vast sums of revenue through its assets, estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars," the US Treasury said in a statement. Six of the people sanctioned are said to be associated with this "secret investment portfolio". The department has also taken aim at a Gaza-based virtual currency exchange, alongside its operator. Reuters/AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US sanctions 10 Hamas members and financial facilitators

children.content: The US Treasury says it has issued new sanctions aimed at disrupting the Hamas militant group's funding, citing "a secret investment portfolio".
The sanctions target 10 Hamas members, operatives and financial facilitators in Gaza and elsewhere, including Sudan, Türkiye, Algeria and Qatar, the department said.

"The United States is taking swift and decisive action to target Hamas’s financiers and facilitators following its brutal and unconscionable massacre of Israeli civilians, including children," Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said.
"We will continue to take all steps necessary to deny Hamas terrorists the ability to raise and use funds to carry out atrocities and terrorize the people of Israel."
The sanctions have been imposed under a terrorism-related executive order.

"In addition to the funds Hamas receives from Iran, its global portfolio of investments generates vast sums of revenue through its assets, estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars," the US Treasury said in a statement.
Six of the people sanctioned are said to be associated with this "secret investment portfolio".
The department has also taken aim at a Gaza-based virtual currency exchange, alongside its operator.
Reuters/AFP

image.altText: A car with a device fitted to measure emissions drives on a rural road.

items.synopsis: A new fuel economy test that takes cars out of the laboratory and puts them on Australian roads is about to uncover how much worse 200 cars, utes and electric vehicles perform in real conditions, and how much more it is really costing Australians.

title.children: Your car's fuel economy is probably worse than advertised. Real-world tests are about to find out how much worse

image.altText: A person with a hood on uses a mobile phone as the sit at an advanced computer set up.

items.synopsis: The South Australian government confirms data belonging to a significant number of people has potentially been accessed through a cyber security breach.

title.children: 'Simply not good enough': SA government impacted by cyber security breach

image.altText: A completely smashed and burnt small car on a country road

items.synopsis: South Australia's road toll climbs to 93 compared to 57 last year after another three fatal crashes.

title.children: 'We need to make this stop': Police urge road users to take care after three fatal crashes in 48 hours

image.altText: A woman leaves court with her face covered.

items.synopsis: Eighty-six dogs were seized north of Adelaide, from a property owned by a woman currently on a good behaviour bond after being found guilty of multiple animal cruelty offences.

title.children: Dogs seized from alleged puppy farm, property owned by previous offender

image.altText: The front of the Port Adelaide Magistrates Court

items.synopsis: Victims had their personal information compromised through a scam linked to the 2022 Optus data breach, with 28 identities used.

title.children: Three Chinese nationals sentenced in Adelaide after using stolen details from phishing scam

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas and Susan Close address media at press conference

items.synopsis: The government says the new institution is set to become the largest educator of domestic students in the country

title.children: Universities of Adelaide and South Australia will merge after government secures enough support to pass legislation

image.altText: Raina Cruise with an angry expression holding her hand up with a man standing next to her who also looks displeased

items.synopsis: A court in Adelaide has heard a female police officer who allegedly had "clumps of actual hair" pulled out of her scalp by an anti-vaccination political candidate feared her head would be repeatedly smashed into the pavement.

title.children: Police officer feared her head would be repeatedly smashed by anti-vaccine protester during alleged assault, trial hears

image.altText: Young girl with tear and soot stained face looks at camera

items.synopsis: A blast at a hospital has become the bloodiest single incident in Gaza since Israel launched an unrelenting bombing campaign against the densely populated territory in retaliation for a deadly cross-border Hamas assault. Here's what we know.

title.children: What we know about the hospital blast that killed hundreds of displaced Gazans

image.altText: US President Joe Biden sits next to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on stage in front of their countrys' flags.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden says he backs Israel's account that an Islamic militant group are responsible for a blast killing a large number of Palestinians at a Gaza hospital.

title.children: President Biden suggests 'other team' to blame for Gaza hospital blast during visit to Tel Aviv

image.altText: Wakame seaweed in Tasmania

items.synopsis: Dredging is halted at a South Australian marina after the discovery of wakame seaweed, regarded as one of the country's worst marine pests.

title.children: 'Noxious' seaweed found in SA for first time by uni student doing an assignment

image.altText: Sir Paul McCartney on stage at the Adelaide Entertainment Centre.

items.synopsis: Sir Paul McCartney's tour Got Back will offer a medley of music from different stages of his six-decade career, and while the show itself is not quite a magical mystery tour, he believes music contains both magic and mystery.

title.children: Sir Paul McCartney reflects on magic, Mozart and dreaming music ahead of opening gig

image.altText: A man and woman smile. They stand on river bank, with a ferry behind them. They hold a small dog in their arms.

items.synopsis: Kristine Sims never imagined she would end up using a publicly available defibrillator after having it installed at a ferry stop on the River Murray.

title.children: Andrew died while waiting for a ferry. His life was saved by his wife and the defibrillator she installed

image.altText: shark carcass lies on the sand along the beach

items.synopsis: Researchers suspect a shark, which washed up on a beach in Victoria's south west, was ripped open by a killer whale in a rarely documented interaction.

title.children: Killer whales vs great white: Fishers shocked as mutilated shark carcass washes up

image.altText: A storm front moves across yachts on Moreton Bay off Brisbane in 2014.

items.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology is closely monitoring a storm system that could develop into an October cyclone in the Coral Sea for the first time on record.

title.children: Weather bureau monitoring possible unprecedented October cyclone off the Queensland coast

image.altText: An image of a fighter jet flying near a warplane

items.synopsis: US military officials say more than 180 intercepts have occurred in the last two years, more than the total over the previous decade.

title.children: Pentagon releases footage of hundreds of aircraft intercepts by Chinese planes

image.altText: Sara Lee

items.synopsis: After 50 years of manufacturing in New South Wales, Sara Lee goes into voluntary administration.

title.children: Sara Lee goes into voluntary administration in Australia

image.altText: Lady in sunglasses walking out with two other women

items.synopsis: After an eight-day district court trial, the jury finds a Sunshine Coast woman guilty of dangerous driving causing the deaths of two young men working on a broken-down bus.

title.children: Courtroom erupts in cheers as driver found guilty over roadside deaths of mechanics

image.altText: Condoleezza Rice and the five spy agency chiefs are seated onstage, with national flags behind them. Mike Burgess is speaking

items.synopsis: ASIO Director General Mike Burgess reveals a Chinese academic was removed from Australia after a foiled attempt to infiltrate a unnamed, prestigious research institution.

title.children: Alleged Chinese spy removed from Australia, ASIO director reveals at Five Eyes meeting

image.altText: Two men wearing suits standing side-by-side behind podiums with microphones

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese welcomes Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka in Canberra as he continues a state visit to Australia

title.children: Australia pledges $68 million to Fiji in budget support as two nations sign an 'elevated' new partnership

image.altText: David Warner walks away

items.synopsis: David Warner has called for more transparency around the accuracy of individual umpire's decisions and greater accountability for their calls.

title.children: Warner calls for umpires to be held accountable at Cricket World Cup

image.altText: A police car blocks a road on a desert-themed movie set.

items.synopsis: The New Mexico-based prosecutors will present their case to a grand jury, noting "additional facts" have come to light about the shooting on the set of the film Rust, which killed Halyna Hutchins.

title.children: Prosecutors seeking to recharge Alec Baldwin over fatal shooting on film set

image.altText: Greta Thunberg in a beanie and wearing a button reading "Oily Money Out" is taken away by police in hi vis uniforms

items.synopsis: The Swedish environmental activist is charged after attempting to disrupt an oil and gas industry conference in London.

title.children: Greta Thunberg charged after climate protest outside London oil and gas forum

image.altText: A group of two Aboriginal women and three kids sit together in front of a house

items.synopsis: People in the remote community of Ltyentye Apurte are pleading with governments to not forget their struggles, following the result of the Voice referendum.

title.children: 'Come live out here': Remote NT community hopes their housing struggles won't be forgotten

image.altText: A middle-aged woman in a purple outfit and weading glasses sits on a plush chair with her hands in her lap.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank's new governor Michele Bullock worries that continuing global supply shocks may entrench inflation expectations and bigger price rises, forcing interest rates higher for longer.

title.children: 'Shock, after shock, after shock' leaves RBA boss worried about persistent high inflation

image.altText: Smiling photo of Selesa Tafaifa

items.synopsis: An expert giving evidence at a coronial inquest into the death of a woman who died in prison after a spit hood was placed over her head, has been stood down from giving further evidence mid-way through questioning.

title.children: 'This report is rubbish': Psychiatrist stood down from giving further evidence at inquest into spit hood death

image.altText: sign covers broken back Funeral Home Improper Body Storage

items.synopsis: Authorities entered the neglected building with a search warrant and found the decomposing bodies in a scene described as horrific.

title.children: 'Abhorrent smell' leads to discovery of 189 decaying bodies in Colorado funeral home

image.altText: A couple of men smoking cigarettes together as they sit in a row

items.synopsis: When Hamas launched its attack, thousands of Gazans who were working in Israel had their permits cancelled. Away from their families, these Palestinians found themselves suddenly trapped in a country that saw them as a threat, with no way to return home.

title.children: These Palestinians were working in Israel when Hamas launched its attack. Suddenly they had no way to return home

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a green wall, smiling. She is wearing a traditional Afghan necklace

items.synopsis: How a TAFE training program is preparing migrant and refugee women for jobs in the construction industry, and giving them the skills to forge a new life for themselves.

title.children: Aziza fled the Taliban, spent five years in refugee camps, and arrived in Australia alone. Now she's literally building her future

image.altText: Scott Edwards is interviewed

items.synopsis: A cricket player who grew up in Australia has become a national hero in The Netherlands after leading the team to a remarkable upset win at the ODI World Cup in India.

title.children: Dutch-Australian inspires one of Cricket World Cup's greatest upsets

image.altText: A composite image of raging bushfire, and a smiling man in high vis.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese has shared his condolences following the death of Richard Mainey, who had been defending his family farm near Kempsey.

title.children: Prime minister pays tribute to man killed in bushfire, expresses concern about upcoming fire season

image.altText: An aerial view of a robot in amongst rows of grape vines.

items.synopsis: To access key markets now, farmers have to prove they are reducing emissions, protecting biodiversity and saving energy and water, but finding the tech to report on all that has been difficult, until now.

title.children: Failed farm technology has left farmers unable to prove their sustainability credentials, until now

image.altText: A cow statue with a crochet rug on it

items.synopsis: When Waroona's beloved bovine landmark 'Mooriel' went missing from the main street, "all hell broke loose" as locals worked to rustle up a mystery ute.

title.children: Herd the one about the country town cow statue that hoofed it to Perth and back?
